xxl.core.cursors.joins
Class SortMergeJoin<I,E>

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<E>
      xxl.core.cursors.joins.SortMergeJoin<I,E>
Type Parameters:
I - the type of the elements consumed by this iteration.
E - the type of the elements returned by this join operation.
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterator<E>, Cursor<E>
Direct Known Subclasses:
Orenstein, PlaneSweep, SortMergeEquivalenceJoin, SortMergeJoin, SortMergeSelfJoin
public class SortMergeJoin<I,E>
extends AbstractCursor<E>

A sort-merge implementation of the join operator. This class provides a generic, untyped sort-merge join algorithm. The resulting tuples of any join operation are generated by a user defined function realizing a kind of factory method. The binary function newResult can be used to map the result tuples to an arbitrary user defined type. The sweep-line status structure, here called sweep-area, consists of a bag with an additional method for reorganisation. The way the elements of the input iterations are inserted into the according sweep-area is determined by a given comparator. Depending on the result of the comparison of the two next input elements of the input iterations, the left (sortedInput0) or right (sortedInput1) input is processed. If the left input is processed, the sweep-area's of sortedInput0 and sortedInput1 are reorganized and the next element of sortedInput0 is inserted in sweepArea0. After that sweepArea1 is queried with this element, i.e., the specified predicate is applied on the elements contained in sweepArea1 and the last inserted element of sweepArea0. In order to perform an effective search in the sweep-area, the query method of the bags should be overriden. If the binary predicate returns true the evaluated tuple gets an result of the join operation. After that query the mapping function to create the result-tuples is applied on the results detected by the predicate and after that they are returned to the user. The right input is processed analogous. The implementation is a bit more complex due to addional checks of join-types and the generation of result-tuples where the evaluated join predicate returned false.

Note: When the given input iteration only implements the interface Iterator it is wrapped to a cursor by a call to the static method wrap.

Example usage (1): 

     LinkedList l1 = new LinkedList();
     final LinkedList l2 = new LinkedList();
     for (int i = 0; i ≤ 10; i++) {
         // left: odd numbers or can be divided by 4
         if (i%2 != 0 || i%4 == 0)
             l1.add(new Integer(i));
         //right: even numbers
         if (i%2 == 0)
             l2.add(new Integer(i));
     }
 
     SortMergeJoin join = new SortMergeJoin(
         l1.listIterator(),
         l2.listIterator(),
         new SortMergeEquiJoinSA(
             new ListSAImplementor(),
             0,
             2
         ),
         new SortMergeEquiJoinSA(
             new ListSAImplementor(),
             1,
             2
         ),
         ComparableComparator.DEFAULT_INSTANCE,
         Function.IDENTITY
     );
 
     join.open();
 
     while (join.hasNext()) {
         Object[] result = (Object[])join.next();
         System.out.println("Tuple: (" + result[0] + ", " + result[1] + ")");
     }
 
     join.close();
The input iterations of this simple example are two list iterators. The first one is based on all odd numbers and numbers that can be divided by 4 of the interval [0, 10]. The second input iterator contains all even numbers of the same interval. The comparator, a default comparator for integers, is used for comparing the elements stored in the sweep-areas based on a list. In this example the specified function to create user defined result-tuples is a rather simple one. The tuplify function delivers the result-tuples in their original representation, namely as an array containing the matching elements of the input iterations. This can simply be seen when printing the result-tuples to the output stream. But in the package xxl.core.relational there are different factory methods creating a particular kind of tuple, e.g., array-tuples, list-tuples, that substitute the tuplify function. So, let us consider the output of this join operation, which looks as follows: 
   [0, 0]
   [4, 4]
   [8, 8]

See Also:
Iterator, Cursor, AbstractCursor, NestedLoopsJoin, SortMergeEquivalenceJoin, SortMergeJoin, Orenstein, PlaneSweep

protected Cursor<? extends I> sortedInput0

protected Cursor<? extends I> sortedInput1
The second (or right) sorted input iteration of the join operator.

sweepArea0

protected SweepArea<I> sweepArea0
The sweep-area that is used for storing the elements of the first input iteration (sortedInput0) and that is probed with elements of the second input iteration (sortedInput1).

sweepArea1

protected SweepArea<I> sweepArea1
The sweep-area that is used for storing the elements of the second input iteration (sortedInput1) and that is probed with elements of the first input iteration (sortedInput0).

queryObject

protected I queryObject
An element of one of the input iteration that is actually used for querying the sweep-area of the other input iteration.

first

protected boolean first
A boolean flag that determines whether the elements stored in queryObject belongs to the first input iteration or not.

comparator

protected Comparator<? super I> comparator
The comparator used to compare the elements of the two input iterations.

newResult

protected Function<? super I,? extends E> newResult
A function that is invoked on each qualifying tuple before it is returned to the caller concerning a call to the next method. This binary function works like a kind of factory method modelling the resulting object (tuple). Be aware that this function possibly has to handle null values in cases of outer joins.

type

protected SortMergeJoin.Type type
The type of this sort-merge join operator. Determines whether it calculates a theta- or an outer-join.

results

protected Iterator<? extends I> results
An iterator holding the precomputed results of the join operator. Because the query method of sweep-area returns an iterator of elements that match the given query, this iterator must be stored to return the remaining elements later.

Constructor Detail

SortMergeJoin

public SortMergeJoin(Iterator<? extends I> sortedInput0,
                     Iterator<? extends I> sortedInput1,
                     SweepArea<I> sweepArea0,
                     SweepArea<I> sweepArea1,
                     Comparator<? super I> comparator,
                     Function<? super I,? extends E> newResult)
Creates a new sort-merge join operator backed on two sorted input iterations using the given sweep-areas to store the input iterations' elements and probe for join results. Furthermore a function named newResult can be specified that is invoked on each qualifying tuple before it is returned to the caller concerning a call to the next method. This function is a kind of factory method to model the resulting object.

Precondition: The input iterations have to be sorted!

Parameters:
sortedInput0 - the first sorted input iteration to be joined.
sortedInput1 - the second sorted input iteration to be joined.
sweepArea0 - the sweep-area used for storing elements of the first sorted input iteration (sortedInput0).
sweepArea1 - the sweep-area used for storing elements of the second sorted input iteration (sortedInput1).
comparator - the comparator that is used for comparing elements of the two sorted input iterations.
newResult - a factory method (function) that takes two parameters as argument and is invoked on each tuple where the predicate's evaluation result is true, i.e., on each qualifying tuple before it is returned to the caller concerning a call to the next method.

SortMergeJoin

public SortMergeJoin(Iterator<? extends I> input0,
                     Iterator<? extends I> input1,
                     Function<? super Iterator<? extends I>,? extends Iterator<? extends I>> newSorter0,
                     Function<? super Iterator<? extends I>,? extends Iterator<? extends I>> newSorter1,
                     SweepArea<I> sweepArea0,
                     SweepArea<I> sweepArea1,
                     Comparator<? super I> comparator,
                     Function<? super I,? extends E> newResult)
Creates a new sort-merge join operator backed on two input iterations using the given sweep-areas to store the input iterations' elements and probe for join results. The constructor does not require the two input iterations to be sorted. The two specified, unary functions newSorter0 and newSorter1 will be invoked on the corresponding input iteration in order to get a sorted input. Furthermore a function named newResult can be specified that is invoked on each qualifying tuple before it is returned to the caller concerning a call to the next method. This function is a kind of factory method to model the resulting object.

Parameters:
input0 - the first input iteration to be joined.
input1 - the second input iteration to be joined.
newSorter0 - an unary function that sorts the first input iteration input0.
newSorter1 - an unary function that sorts the second input iteration input1.
sweepArea0 - the sweep-area used for storing elements of the first input iteration (input0).
sweepArea1 - the sweep-area used for storing elements of the second input iteration (input1).
comparator - the comparator that is used for comparing elements of the two input iterations.
newResult - a factory method (function) that takes two parameters as argument and is invoked on each tuple where the predicate's evaluation result is true, i.e., on each qualifying tuple before it is returned to the caller concerning a call to the next method.

SortMergeJoin

public SortMergeJoin(Iterator<? extends I> sortedInput0,
                     Iterator<? extends I> sortedInput1,
                     Function<?,? extends SweepArea<I>> newSweepArea,
                     Comparator<? super I> comparator,
                     Function<? super I,? extends E> newResult)
Creates a new sort-merge join operator backed on two sorted input iterations using a parameterless function to create the required sweep-areas that are used to store the input iterations' elements and probe for join results. Furthermore a function named newResult can be specified that is invoked on each qualifying tuple before it is returned to the caller concerning a call to the next method. This function is a kind of factory method to model the resulting object.

Precondition: The input iterations have to be sorted!

Parameters:
sortedInput0 - the first sorted input iteration to be joined.
sortedInput1 - the second sorted input iteration to be joined.
newSweepArea - a parameterless function creating a new sweep-area that is used for storing elements of the sorted input iterations.
comparator - the comparator that is used for comparing elements of the two sorted input iterations.
newResult - a factory method (function) that takes two parameters as argument and is invoked on each tuple where the predicate's evaluation result is true, i.e., on each qualifying tuple before it is returned to the caller concerning a call to the next method.
Method Detail

getFirst

protected boolean getFirst()
Returns whether an element of the first input iteration is responsible for the actual element of the sort-based join operator, i.e., if an element of the first input iteration has been probed against the second sweep-area to produce actual element. The implementation simply returns the field first.

Returns:
the value of the filed first.

open

public void open()
Opens the join operator, i.e., signals the cursor to reserve resources, open the input iteration, etc. Before a cursor has been opened calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Therefore open must be called before a cursor's data can be processed. Multiple calls to open do not have any effect, i.e., if open was called the cursor remains in the state opened until its close method is called.

Note, that a call to the open method of a closed cursor usually does not open it again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

Specified by:
open in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
open in class AbstractCursor<E>

close

public void close()
Closes the cursor, i.e., signals the cursor to clean up resources, close input iterations and sweep-areas, etc. When a cursor has been closed calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Multiple calls to close do not have any effect, i.e., if close was called the cursor remains in the state closed.

Note, that a closed cursor usually cannot be opened again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

Specified by:
close in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
close in class AbstractCursor<E>

hasNextObject

protected boolean hasNextObject()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

Specified by:
hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor<E>
Returns:
true if the cursor has more elements.

nextObject

protected E nextObject()
Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the cursor's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more.

Specified by:
nextObject in class AbstractCursor<E>
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.

reset

public void reset()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
Resets the sort-merge join operator to its initial state such that the caller is able to traverse the join result again without constructing a new join operator (optional operation).

Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors.

Specified by:
reset in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
reset in class AbstractCursor<E>
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset operation is not supported by the cursor.

supportsReset

public boolean supportsReset()
Returns true if the reset operation is supported by the sort-merge join operator. Otherwise it returns false.

Specified by:
supportsReset in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
supportsReset in class AbstractCursor<E>
Returns:
true if the reset operation is supported by the sort-merge join operator, otherwise false.

toString

public String toString()
Returns a string representation of the object. In general, the toString method returns a string that "textually represents" this object. The result should be a concise but informative representation that is easy for a person to read. It is recommended that all subclasses override this method.

Overrides:
